messages.content:
Objective: Write code for a large system design task.
Please note that the code should be fully functional. No placeholders.
Only use the functions you have been provided with.
Only use the `write_files` to output code.

You must act autonomously and you will receive no human input at any stage. You have to return as output the complete code for completing this task, and correctly incorporate it into the existing code base.
You always write out the whole file contents. You always indent code with tabs.
Please always view the files before writing to them, to make sure you are writing to the correct files.
When writing a test, make the filename start with the prefix 'test_'.

Provide the minimal code necessary to achieve the task conditioned on the existing generated code---including changing the existing generated code.

You cannot visualize any graphical output. You exist within a Actor Model machine, and when you list out steps, each step will be taken by a new separate sub-ChatGPT model. When you list out a sub-task steps, you can optionally specify the sub-task validation to check that it has been completed successfully.

You cannot use any databases as none are setup in the local environment, instead mock a database with an in memory dictionary to store data. No data saved to disk will persist between steps or write operations.
                               
If a test is failing the error could be the code, or the test is incorrect, so feel free to overwrite and change the tests when they are incorrect, to make all tests pass.

Use the functions provided. When calling functions only provide a RFC8259 compliant JSON request following this format without deviation.

steps: 1. Start by setting up the project structure and creating the necessary files. This includes the main application file (app.py), a file for handling user accounts (user.py), a file for handling transactions (transaction.py), a file for handling budgets and goals (budget.py), a file for handling investments (investment.py), a file for handling analytics and reporting (analytics.py), a file for handling notifications and alerts (notifications.py), and a file for handling customer support (support.py). Also, create a requirements.txt file to list all the necessary dependencies. After setting up the project structure, write a test to ensure that all the files exist and can be imported correctly.

2. Implement the user account management system. This includes functions for creating a new user account, logging in, and password recovery. Use a secure method for storing passwords, such as hashing. Also, implement a mock database using an in-memory dictionary to store user data. After implementing the user account management system, write tests to ensure that new accounts can be created, users can log in with valid credentials, and password recovery works correctly.

3. Implement the income and expense tracking system. This includes functions for adding new transactions, categorizing transactions, and identifying recurring transactions. Transactions should be stored in the mock database, associated with the user who made them. After implementing the income and expense tracking system, write tests to ensure that transactions can be added, categorized, and identified as recurring correctly.

4. Implement the bank account integration system. This includes functions for linking a bank account, importing transactions from a linked account, and updating account balances and transactions in real time. Since we can't connect to a real bank account, simulate these features using mock data. After implementing the bank account integration system, write tests to ensure that accounts can be linked, transactions can be imported, and account balances and transactions can be updated correctly.

5. Implement the budgeting and goals system. This includes functions for setting monthly budget goals, alerting users when they are nearing or exceed budget limits, and tracking progress towards financial goals. Budgets and goals should be stored in the mock database, associated with the user who set them. After implementing the budgeting and goals system, write tests to ensure that budgets can be set, alerts are triggered correctly, and progress can be tracked correctly.

6. Implement the investment tracking system. This includes functions for adding and tracking investment portfolios, providing an overview of investment performance, and setting custom alerts for significant changes in investment values. Investments should be stored in the mock database, associated with the user who added them. After implementing the investment tracking system, write tests to ensure that investments can be added and tracked, performance can be calculated, and alerts can be set correctly.

7. Implement the analytics and reporting system. This includes functions for generating monthly financial reports, providing visual analytics for spending habits and trends, and comparing year-on-year financial data. After implementing the analytics and reporting system, write tests to ensure that reports can be generated, analytics can be provided, and year-on-year comparisons can be made correctly.

8. Implement the savings tips and recommendations system. This includes functions for providing personalized tips for saving money and recommending financial products based on user profiles. After implementing the savings tips and recommendations system, write tests to ensure that tips can be provided and recommendations can be made correctly.

9. Implement the notifications and alerts system. This includes functions for setting customizable notifications for upcoming bills and payments, and alerting users of unusual account activity or potential fraud. After implementing the notifications and alerts system, write tests to ensure that notifications can be set and alerts can be triggered correctly.

10. Implement the customer support system. This includes functions for providing in-app customer support chat, a FAQ section, and user guides. Also, provide email and phone support options. Since we can't provide real customer support, simulate these features using mock data. After implementing the customer support system, write tests to ensure that all support options can be provided correctly.
step: 2. Implement the user account management system. This includes functions for creating a new user account, logging in, and password recovery. Use a secure method for storing passwords, such as hashing. Also, implement a mock database using an in-memory dictionary to store user data. After implementing the user account management system, write tests to ensure that new accounts can be created, users can log in with valid credentials, and password recovery works correctly.

You will get instructions for code to write.
First lay out the names of the core classes, functions, methods that will be necessary, As well as a quick comment on their purpose.
Do not comment on what every file does. Please note that the code should be fully functional. No placeholders.

You will start with the "entrypoint" file, then go to the ones that are imported by that file, and so on.
Please note that the code should be fully functional. No placeholders.

Follow a language and framework appropriate best practice file naming convention.
Make sure that files contain all imports, types etc.  The code should be fully functional. Make sure that code in different files are compatible with each other.
When writing code if you are unsure, write a plausible implementation.
Include module dependency or package manager dependency definition file.

Useful to know:

For Python, you always create an appropriate requirements.txt file.
Always add a comment briefly describing the purpose of the function definition.
Add comments explaining very complex bits of logic.
Always follow the best practices for the requested languages for folder/file structure and how to package the project.
You can use any package and any other packages you wish to install.
You cannot use any databases as none are setup in the local environment, instead mock a database with an in memory dictionary to store data. No data saved to disk will persis between steps or write operations.
When writing a test, make the filename start with the prefix 'test_'.
                                       
Python toolbelt preferences:
- pytest
- dataclasses
- flask

Objective:```
### **Personal Finance Tracker**

**Overview**:
A tool designed to assist users in managing their personal finances by tracking income, expenses, and investments, setting budget goals, and providing financial insights and analytics.

**Functional Requirements to Implement**:

1. **Account Management**:
   - [ ] 1.1. Users can create and manage their accounts.
   - [ ] 1.2. Secure login and authentication system.
   - [ ] 1.3. Password recovery and user data encryption for security.

2. **Income and Expense Tracking**:
   - [ ] 2.1. Users can manually enter or upload income and expense data.
   - [ ] 2.2. Categorize transactions (e.g., groceries, utilities, salary).
   - [ ] 2.3. The system automatically classifies recurring transactions.

3. **Bank Account Integration**:
   - [ ] 3.1. Users can link multiple bank accounts.
   - [ ] 3.2. Automatic import of transactions from linked accounts.
   - [ ] 3.3. Real-time updates of account balances and transactions.

4. **Budgeting and Goals**:
   - [ ] 4.1. Users can set monthly budget goals for different categories.
   - [ ] 4.2. The system alerts users when they are nearing or exceed budget limits.
   - [ ] 4.3. Progress tracking towards financial goals.

5. **Investment Tracking**:
   - [ ] 5.1. Users can add and track their investment portfolios.
   - [ ] 5.2. Overview of investment performance (e.g., ROI, current value).
   - [ ] 5.3. Custom alerts for significant changes in investment values.

6. **Analytics and Reporting**:
   - [ ] 6.1. Monthly financial reports summarizing income, expenses, and savings.
   - [ ] 6.2. Visual analytics for spending habits and trends.
   - [ ] 6.3. Year-on-year financial comparison.

7. **Savings Tips and Recommendations**:
   - [ ] 7.1. The system provides personalized tips for saving money.
   - [ ] 7.2. Recommendations for financial products based on user profiles.

8. **Notifications and Alerts**:
   - [ ] 8.1. Customizable notifications for upcoming bills and payments.
   - [ ] 8.2. Alerts for unusual account activity or potential fraud.

9. **Data Security and Privacy**:
   - [ ] 9.1. Strong data encryption and privacy protection measures.
   - [ ] 9.2. Regular security audits and compliance with financial regulations.

10. **Mobile App and Web Interface**:
    - [ ] 10.1. Cross-platform accessibility (iOS, Android, Web).
    - [ ] 10.2. User-friendly interface and easy navigation.

11. **Customer Support**:
    - [ ] 11.1. In-app customer support chat.
    - [ ] 11.2. FAQ section and user guides.
    - [ ] 11.3. Email and phone support options.
```

Understand the problem, by creating an extremely detailed step-by-step plan, where each step is long (multiple sentences) and in total includes every single feature requirement specified above, feel free to copy directly from it. Use no more than 10 steps in the plan. Create additional tests, checks and evaluation at each step when applicable to help make an excellent code implementation, where all the code is fully functional. Use best software design practices, and you can output large amounts of code at once. Please include a last sentence to create and run tests when implementing or writing code in that same step. You will receive no human input at any stage, so you cannot use a human to test. Only create a detailed plan to begin with, which includes designing and running tests to check that they all pass. Please be sure to include all of the specified feature requirements in the following plan.
